H0.text: Atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration changes are the phenomena whose climatic impact scientists can predict by correlating the climatic conditions recorded in ice cores with the solid, nonsnow particles also found in the ice.

H1.text: Radioactive decay rate changes in the outer core are the phenomena whose climatic impact scientists can help predict by correlating climatic conditions recorded in ice cores with solid, nonsnow particles also found in the ice.

H2.text: Volcanic eruptions are the phenomena whose climatic impact can be predicted by scientists who use ice cores to identify and explain previous climatic trends, correlating climatic conditions recorded in the ice with solid, nonsnow particles also found in the ice.

H3.text: Magnetic pole reversals are the phenomena whose climatic impact can be predicted by scientists who use ice cores to identify and explain previous climatic trends and correlate climatic conditions recorded in the ice with solid, nonsnow particles also found in the ice.

A4.text: Further research has demonstrated a reliable correlation between CO2 levels and the temperature calculated from ice isotope data.

A5.text: In cases where volcanic tephra is interspersed with ice, it can be dated using argon/argon dating and hence provide fixed points for dating the ice.

A6.text: Ice cores provide evidence for greenhouse gas concentration variations over the past 800,000 years.
